headline: Her Daughter Was Killed by a Gang. She Has a Message for Trump.
keywords: ['Gangs', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Evelyn Rodriguez’s grief has fueled a crusade against the MS-13 gang. But some fear her meeting with the president Friday will fuel an anti-immigration agenda.
lead_paragraph: BRENTWOOD, N.Y. — These days, Evelyn Rodriguez always carries her blue clipboard, jotting down notes when inspiration or anxiety strikes. It has been her constant companion in the 10 months since her 16-year-old daughter, Kayla Cuevas, was killed by members of the transnational MS-13 gang.

headline: Giant Telescope Atop Hawaii’s Mauna Kea Should Be Approved, Judge Says
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The Thirty Meter Telescope, which would be the largest in the Northern Hemisphere, could survey black holes and planets orbiting distant stars, but opponents say it would desecrate a sacred mountain.
lead_paragraph: The stars are still in reach for astronomers who want to build a $1.4 billion telescope on top of Hawaii’s Mauna Kea.

headline: U.S. Senate, Jerusalem, Jeff Bezos: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Godello From Spain
abstract: This white grape almost disappeared from Spain in the middle of the 20th century, but a dedicated group succeeded in reviving it.
lead_paragraph: Wine is full of places and grapes that were virtually unknown 10 or 15 years ago. We’ve covered several of these, including assyrtiko from Santorini and the reds of Ribeira Sacra.

headline: Giving New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc a Second Chance
abstract: Consumers may hold strong opinions about certain kinds of wine, but occasionally revisiting those biases opens people up to new pleasures.
lead_paragraph: The last few weeks of Wine School have been as much of an education for me as they may have been for anybody else.

headline: Review: ‘Pete the Cat,’ a Kitty Rocker Who Refuses to Be a Pet
abstract: For its free summer theater program, Theatreworks USA has adapted a children’s book series featuring a laid-back, guitar-playing feline hero.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that cats love to shred. But the shredding Pete enjoys is far more likely to damage your eardrums than your couch. This cat plays a mean guitar, and while some members of his species merely expect to be treated like rock stars, Pete really is one.

headline: A Godard Riff That Adapts Rousseau’s Treatise on Education
abstract: “Le Gai Savoir,” a series of conversations between two young militants, arrived in 1969 after Jean-Luc Godard said he was done making movies.
lead_paragraph: For many, Jean-Luc Godard’s great period began with “Breathless” in 1960 and culminated less than a decade later with “Weekend,” a movie that has a final title declaring the end of cinema. But there was also a nearly forgotten feature that extended this glorious run.

headline: Review: Cosplay and Comedy in ‘Brigsby Bear’
abstract: In this absurdly charming film, Kyle Mooney plays an obsessed fan who discovers that there is an entire world waiting for him beyond his TV.
lead_paragraph: The absurd and absurdly charming “Brigsby Bear” sounds, well, unbearable. It’s the story of a young man who, after decades of being shut away from the world, splashes down in it like a space alien. There are reasons for his re-entry, though that’s getting ahead of the story, which uses a queasy crime as a jumping-off point to spin a largely sweet, often very funny fairy tale about the perils and the sustaining pleasures of obsessive fandom. Mostly, it is an account of one man’s great, mad love, one that’s mocked, tested and deemed near-pathological — a familiar plight for many superfans.

headline: Three Reasons to Watch ‘Picnic at Hanging Rock’
abstract: The disappearance of three girls and their teacher in 1900 rocks a small Australian town in this provocative mystery from Peter Weir.
lead_paragraph: Peter Weir’s haunting drama “Picnic at Hanging Rock” is one of the most celebrated films in Australian cinema, a subtle and indelible mystery that has unsettled audiences since its foreign debut in 1975. As it does in many of Australia’s best-known films (“Walkabout,” “The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert” and the “Mad Max” series), the Outback plays a significant part in the story — when three schoolgirls and a teacher go missing there on a Valentine’s Day picnic in 1900, their wild environment becomes more than just a backdrop, it’s an unknown world that’s more menacing than majestic.

headline: Review: ‘An Inconvenient Sequel,’ With Al Gore Keeping the Pressure On
abstract: A follow-up to “An Inconvenient Truth,” with new information on climate change and even some positive developments.
lead_paragraph: In a summer movie landscape with Spider-Man, a simian army waging further battle for the planet and Charlize Theron as a sexy Cold War-era superspy, it says something that one of the most compelling characters is Al Gore.

headline: SpaceX Is Now One of the World’s Most Valuable Privately Held Companies
abstract: Elon Musk’s rocket company raised $350 million in new financing, raising its valuation to about $21 billion.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — SpaceX, the rocket maker founded by billionaire Elon Musk, has raised up to $350 million in new financing and is now valued at around $21 billion, making it one of the most valuable privately held companies in the world.

headline: Review: ‘Menashe’ Finds Faith and Fatherhood Sometimes at Odds
abstract: In this sweet, often understated film set in a Hasidic neighborhood, the title character is a widower who must remarry to regain custody of his son.
lead_paragraph: My heart broke a little near the end of “Menashe,” a sweet comedy that’s not without a bit of sadness. For sure, this funny and tender film prompts cheerful smiles, but sometimes they turn melancholy.

headline: Review: ‘From the Land of the Moon,’ and on Uneven Ground
abstract: Nicole Garcia’s turgid adaptation of an Italian novella makes for a silly movie, despite a strong performance from Marion Cotillard.
lead_paragraph: A full accounting of the silliness of “From the Land of the Moon” requires revealing a surprise near the end. Few viewers are likely to make it that far, so let’s start where many will stop: the English-language title, whose meaning is never clarified.

headline: Review: In Search of a Dying Tongue in ‘I Dream in Another Language’
abstract: In the film, a linguist seeks to keep a language alive, but the only two men who speak it aren’t interested.
lead_paragraph: This is one of those movies in which every shot is beautiful. Conventionally beautiful, that is. “I Dream in Another Language” features lush tropical landscapes and attractive, compelling people, always lit — not quite just so (the filmmakers clearly know better) — with exemplary attention to the most eye-catching detail. It’s delectably watchable.

headline: Review: Holly Hunter and Carrie Coon Try to Redeem ‘Strange Weather’
abstract: In this road movie, a woman whose son has committed suicide travels to confront the hot-dog tycoon who stole her son’s idea.
lead_paragraph: It may be time to retire the type of road movie in which the protagonist, ostensibly on an urgent journey, insists on taking back roads — partly because she doesn’t like trucks, she says, but really because a quick drive on the Interstate wouldn’t sustain a feature.

headline: Dr. Herbert Needleman, Who Saw Lead’s Wider Harm to Children, Dies at 89
abstract: Dr. Needleman studied lost baby teeth to show that any level of absorbed lead can damage young brains.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Herbert Needleman, whose studies of children exposed to low levels of lead prompted regulations that limited or banned the metal in a range of common products, like gasoline and paint, and set a standard for the modern study of environmental toxins, died on July 18 in Pittsburgh. He was 89.

headline: Review: Diamonds Are a Mighty Tease in ‘Imperfections,’ a Noir Set in Chicago
abstract: David Singer’s film is a modest con movie about the lengths an aspiring actress is willing to go to for some extra cash.
lead_paragraph: The title “Imperfections” doesn’t lie: Viewers of David Singer’s microbudgeted directorial debut will have to endure plenty of baggy scenes and awkward exchanges to enjoy the upside of this modest con movie, which has the charming, almost anachronistic noir setting of Chicago’s Jewelers Row district. (As a former Chicagoan, I’ll confess to some affection for the location, around the corner from the city’s main screening room for movie critics.)

headline: Review: ‘The Last Dalai Lama?’ Asks What Comes Next
abstract: This documentary examines why the Dalai Lama is being careful to protect his lineage from Chinese interference.
lead_paragraph: A surplus of wisdom and benevolence radiates from “The Last Dalai Lama?,” written and directed by Mickey Lemle, the filmmaker of “Compassion in Exile” (1993), another documentary about this Buddhist leader, who is 82.

headline: Review: Aid Workers in Love and War in Sean Penn’s ‘The Last Face’
abstract: In war-torn Liberia, Charlize Theron and Javier Bardem face a big problem: how to keep their knotty relationship from fizzling.
lead_paragraph: Sean Penn has some significant experience as a human-rights activist. He has shown commendable stalwartness in walking the walk, so to speak, not just starting a foundation to help victims of  Haiti’s 2010 earthquake but traveling there to help on the ground. We can read Mr. Penn’s latest directorial effort, “The Last Face,” as a kind of tribute to the aid workers he has met. As well meaning as this movie is, it is also a turgid, muddled one.

headline: A Couple of Punks Who Just Won’t Quit
abstract: They are known in punk rock circles as simply Dennis and Lois, two superfans who are still going to concerts and shows, and bonding with the bands.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Anderson and Lois Kahlert’s first date was in 1975 at CBGB, the seminal East Village club. Talking Heads and another band, Television, were on the bill and Lou Reed was shooting pool.

headline: Ukraine’s President Sidelines Opponent by Stripping His Citizenship
abstract: Mikheil Saakashvili, a former Georgian president who moved to Ukraine to help fight corruption, went from being President Petro O. Poroshenko’s ally to his opponent.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Once they were prominent allies in opposing the Kremlin: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine and the former president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili. Mr. Saakashvili even went so far as to emigrate to Ukraine to serve as a regional governor under Mr. Poroshenko.

headline: Review: In ‘Person to Person,’ the Real-ish Humans of New York
abstract: Dustin Guy Defa wrote and directed this low-budget feature that tells the stories of several New Yorkers over the course of a day.
lead_paragraph: Despite some notable names in “Person to Person,” it’s the lesser-known actors who leave an impression. But maybe that’s not entirely surprising for a movie loosely about authenticity and the little absurdities that abound in New York City.

headline: Review: ‘Sled Dogs’ Exposes Abuse of Working Animals
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Dog Sledding', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race (Alaska)']
abstract: The documentary filmmaker Fern Levitt wants to shut down the dog-sledding industry. She makes a moving argument.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to fall in love with the animals in “Sled Dogs.” It’s thornier to sift through the words of the handlers and mushers — many of whom seem to genuinely care for the dogs — and determine how pervasive abuse is in dog-sledding ventures.

headline: Review: ‘Turn It Around’ Plays to Fans of West Coast Punk Music
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: A sprawling documentary retraces the birth of the punk scene in the Bay Area, where bands like Green Day and Rancid came together and thrived.
lead_paragraph: Punk history is full of lurid misadventures, and Corbett Redford’s thorough documentary, “Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk,” collects many of those “you had to be there” stories for a lively — if lengthy — chronicle of the Northern California punk scene, beginning in the late 1970s.

headline: Review: ‘Water and Sugar’: How Carlo Di Palma Burnished Reality on Film
abstract: This documentary celebrates the Italian cinematographer who brought a golden touch to his collaborations with Michelangelo Antonioni and Woody Allen.
lead_paragraph: When the Italian cinematographer Carlo Di Palma started out, he was a 15-year-old camera assistant on “Ossessione,” the 1943 Luchino Visconti movie that is widely considered the first Italian neorealist film. The new documentary “Water and Sugar: Carlo Di Palma, the Colours of Life” explores Di Palma’s long career, from that auspicious beginning to his work on “Red Desert,” “Radio Days” and some of the other best films of the 20th century.

headline: What’s New in NYC Theater
abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages — and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: Review: Amazon’s ‘Last Tycoon’ Is Slick but Short on Passion
abstract: This streaming series, inspired by the F. Scott Fitzgerald novel, stars Matt Bomer, Kelsey Grammer and Lily Collins.
lead_paragraph: “The Last Tycoon,” Amazon’s new series inspired by the F. Scott Fitzgerald novel, is certainly meticulous — the period costumes, the hairdos, the historical references. Yet attention to detail doesn’t buy passion, either in romance or in recreating the tumult of the 1930s. The show, which becomes available to stream on Friday, looks great, as do the people in it, but caring about any of them doesn’t come easily.

headline: Whooping Cough Cases Double in Indiana in a Year, Prompting a Call to Vaccinate
abstract: There were 136 confirmed cases of whooping cough in the state in the first half of 2017, compared with 66 in the first half of 2016, but an expert was not alarmed.
lead_paragraph: The number of whooping cough cases in Indiana has doubled in the past year, state health officials warned on Thursday, urging parents to make sure their children are vaccinated.

headline: A Trendy Way to Protect Your Hair From Heat Damage
abstract: Nneka Ibeabuchi, the creative director of the “Beads and Braids” photo series, demonstrates how to create a summer hairstyle that she discovered in Ghana.
lead_paragraph: Nneka Ibeabuchi, a creative director and hair stylist originally from Nigeria, came up with the concept on her Instagram page for the “Beads and Braids” photo project when she took a trip to Ghana in December. “I fell in love with Ghana’s culture and wanted to come back and tell everybody how my trip was,” she said.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from editors and critics at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Two new books about Syria go beyond the headlines, bearing witness to the lives of citizens whose world has been shattered by six years of war. Roxane Gay’s memoir reaches into the depths of trauma, memory and desire. A biography of Henry David Thoreau brings the 19th-century environmentalist into timely focus. And a thriller set at the zoo will set your pulse racing, as a mother draws on every survival instinct she has to keep her son safe from gunmen. All these, and more, in this week’s recommended books.

headline: 3 Books That Delve Into What Work Means to Us
abstract: The workplace is evolving, as is our relationship to it. These three novels explore how work interacts with our personal lives.
lead_paragraph: Work, and our relationship to it, is evolving. On Thursday, Google.org, the tech giant’s philanthropic arm, announced a $50 million initiative to support organizations preparing people for the changing job market. Employee priorities are shifting, and companies, particularly in the tech world, are responding by offering enhanced benefits, more flex time (like summer hours) and other in-office perks. In the three novels below, the characters’ time at the office interacts with their personal lives in various ways — in one case the former threatens to completely engulf the latter.

headline: On the Touchy Subject of Class in America
abstract: Paul Fussell’s 1983 book, “Class: A Guide Through the American Status System,” plunges into the harsh realities of social divisions.
lead_paragraph: CLASSA Guide Through the American Status SystemBy Paul Fussell202 pages. Touchstone Books. $16.

headline: Review: In ‘Somewhere Between,’ It’s Groundhog Week
abstract: A remake on ABC of a complicated South Korean drama sends a mother back in time to try to prevent her daughter’s murder.
lead_paragraph: In ABC’s new dead-child time-travel mystery, “Somewhere Between,” the coincidences are somewhere between far-fetched and lunatic.

headline: Diversity Concerns Prompt ‘Great Comet’ Casting Shakeup
abstract: After a social media storm over the musical’s plan to replace Okieriete Onaodowan, Mandy Patinkin declined to assume the lead male role.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway legend Mandy Patinkin said Friday he was canceling a plan to join the cast of “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812” after an uproar on social media over the fact that the show brought in Mr. Patinkin, who is white, to replace an African-American actor, Okieriete “Oak” Onaodowan.

headline: Thomas P. Campbell, Former Met Chief Executive, Gets Fellowship
abstract: Mr. Campbell will pursue research at the Getty in Los Angeles and Waddesdon Manor in Buckinghamshire, England. He left the Met museum last month.
lead_paragraph: Thomas P. Campbell, who last month ended his tumultuous tenure as chief executive of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been chosen as the second recipient of the Getty Rothschild Fellowship, the J. Paul Getty Museum and the Rothschild Foundation announced on Thursday.

headline: With New Sanctions, Senate Forces Trump’s Hand on Russia
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The sanctions force President Trump to either take a hard line against Russia or appear soft on Moscow during investigations into election meddling.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Thursday approved sweeping sanctions against Russia, forcing President Trump to decide whether to accept a tougher line against Moscow or issue a politically explosive veto amid investigations into ties between his presidential campaign and Russian officials.

headline: Lucas Duda Traded to Rays for Reliever Drew Smith
abstract: The Mets sent Duda, a 31-year-old first baseman, to Tampa Bay in what may be the first of a number of deals they make before the trade deadline.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — In what may be the first of several moves by the Mets to look to the future, the team dealt first baseman Lucas Duda, their mild-mannered power hitter, to the Tampa Bay Rays on Thursday.

abstract: Our guide to dance performances.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to dance performances.

headline: Animals, Abandoned and Starving, Are Evacuated From Zoo in Syria
abstract: Three lions, two tigers, two bears and two hyenas were trucked to Turkey from Aalim al Sahar, or Magic World, near Aleppo, after being kept alive by locals.
lead_paragraph: Nine animals that had been kept alive — barely — at a damaged zoo on the outskirts of Aleppo, Syria, were evacuated and taken to a rehabilitation center in Turkey last week.

headline: M.T.A. Plans ‘Adopt-a-Station’ Program for Subways
abstract: The corporate sponsorship program, part of an “all hands on deck” approach to fixing the century-old subway system, could upgrade as many as 72 stations.
lead_paragraph: At a time when New York City’s subway system is in crisis, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made a plea to private companies on Thursday: Help us improve it by adopting a station.

abstract: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: Sessions’ Gratuitous Attack on Gay Workers
abstract: The latest blow to civil rights comes at a moment of tremendous promise for L.G.B.T. equality.
lead_paragraph: In a court filing on Wednesday, the Justice Department told the federal court of appeals in New York that employers should be free to fire lesbian, gay and bisexual people under federal law.

keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The blunt lingo of President Trump and his new communications director, Anthony Scaramucci, can sometimes sound like a cross between “Goodfellas” and “The Wolf of Wall Street.”
lead_paragraph: The blunt lingo of President Trump and his new communications director, Anthony Scaramucci, can sometimes sound like a cross between “Goodfellas” and “The Wolf of Wall Street.”

headline: Rikers Inmate Spent His Brief Escape Hiding in Bushes
abstract: Officials are investigating how up to four guards who were supposed to be watching Naquan Hill allowed him breach the perimeter of a high-security area at the city jail complex.
lead_paragraph: Aside from a few cuts and scrapes from razor wire, Naquan Hill had little to show for his attempted escape from Rikers Island on Wednesday.

headline: Rocky, Nell, Witch Hazel and More: A Sampling of June Foray
abstract: Ms. Foray’s voices could be heard over decades of animated films and television shows.
lead_paragraph: June Foray’s many voices were an indelible soundtrack for generations of eager cartoon watchers. During her decades-long career, Ms. Foray, who died on Wednesday in Los Angeles, spoke for dozens of characters, ranging from mischievous miscreants to wide-eyed innocents. Here are some of our favorites.

headline: Matt Kuchar’s Dizzying Week Continues, With Lightheadedness
abstract: After falling short in the British Open to Jordan Spieth, golf’s Mr. Sunshine felt lightheaded at the Canadian Open, but finished his round.
lead_paragraph: OAKVILLE, Ontario — If anybody can survive losing a duel with Jordan Spieth at the British Open, it is Matt Kuchar, golf’s Mr. Sunshine.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Putin Derides American Sanctions and Trump Investigations as ‘Boorishness’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 28, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “It is impossible to put up forever with this boorishness toward our country.”

headline: If a Standing Desk Is Good, What About a Standing Commute?
abstract: Looking on the bright side of a plan to take out some seats from subway cars, standing would most likely let commuters eat an extra Life Saver a day.
lead_paragraph: In relentless pursuit of silver linings, we bring you research on the benefits of standing vs. sitting, as transit officials prepare to remove seats from some subway cars on the L line and the 42nd Street shuttle.

headline: Brooklyn’s Anti-Gentrification Restaurant
abstract: The world-renowned chef Claus Meyer is behind a new culinary center in Brownsville meant to serve the poor — and Williamsburg is not invited.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Lucas Denton was shopping at the Scratchbread Bakery in Bedford-Stuyvesant when he noticed a large man, seemingly unfamiliar with that part of Brooklyn, gesticulating and speaking loudly on the sidewalk in what Mr. Denton described as “an Elven language.” His impulse was to welcome him to the neighborhood, he recounted recently, “and maybe calm him down a touch.” Mr. Denton, then in his late 20s, had developed an appreciation for fashion but food culture remained alien to him; so it signified nothing when the man said that his name was Claus Meyer.

headline: Catholic Church May Cash In on Air Rights in Midtown Rezoning Deal
abstract: The City Council on Thursday took a step toward the long-awaited rezoning of East Midtown, with even taller office towers in store for the business hub.
lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York may know something about divine intervention. But to get to Mayor Bill de Blasio on a real estate negotiation potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars, it hired lobbyists.

headline: Ben McAdoo Opens Giants’ Camp With Lesson From a Lion Lothario
abstract: When players arrived for the first day of training camp on Thursday, the coach welcomed them with two dramatic readings.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When players arrive for training camp, it is customary for an N.F.L. coach to deliver a motivational message to his team. The typical themes of such speeches are perseverance, teamwork, toughness.

headline: Literary World Reacts to Michiko Kakutani’s Departure
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Did Michiko Kakutani — who stepped down after 38 years as The Times’s chief book critic — influence your literary tastes? We’d like to hear about it.
lead_paragraph: A knock from Michiko Kakutani could take a writer down a peg. Or a warm appraisal by The New York Times’s longstanding chief book critic could anoint a previously unknown talent.

headline: The Tampa Bay Rays Are Unlikely Contenders Again
abstract: After a 94-loss debacle, an A.L. East team rediscovers its resourceful side as it tries to return to the postseason.
lead_paragraph: The history of Tampa Bay’s major league baseball team divides neatly in half — 10 seasons as the stumbling and hopeless Devil Rays, 10 more as the clever and resourceful Rays. Last season’s 94-loss debacle did not fit with the revival, but the Rays earned their last-place finish in the American League East and the skepticism that followed them to spring training.

headline: Call It ‘Sneaky Repeal,’ Not ‘Skinny Repeal’
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ending the individual mandate would raise premiums and eliminate insurance for 16 million people.
lead_paragraph: News Update: The Senate rejected a scaled-down Republican plan to repeal parts of the Affordable Care Act in the early hours of Friday morning. Senator John McCain cast the decisive vote to defeat the proposal.

headline: Wells Fargo Forced Unwanted Auto Insurance on Borrowers

headline: The Emptiness of Trump’s Promises of Tolerance
abstract: The identity politics of the president’s supporters have always been deceptively complicated — but his own have been less so.
lead_paragraph: In December, seven months before President Trump announced his intention to ban transgender people from serving in the military, I attended one of Trump’s postelection victory rallies, in Grand Rapids, Mich., with a Trump supporter named Jayne Locke. As it happened, Locke was a transgender veteran. This was not one of those journalistic exercises in deliberate expectation-thwarting; it had happened more or less by chance. On my way to Grand Rapids, I had been canvassing Facebook looking for Trump supporters who were going to the rally, and Locke was the one who wrote me back. When she did, she was quick to note something that was not readily apparent from her Facebook page: “I’m not sure if you are aware of this or not, but I am not only a Trump supporter but also a transsexual woman Trump supporter.”

headline: Artificial Intelligence Is Stuck. Here’s How to Move It Forward.
abstract: Real progress will require an international scientific collaboration, like the one that discovered the Higgs boson.
lead_paragraph: Artificial Intelligence is colossally hyped these days, but the dirty little secret is that it still has a long, long way to go. Sure, A.I. systems have mastered an array of games, from chess and Go to “Jeopardy” and poker, but the technology continues to struggle in the real world. Robots fall over while opening doors, prototype driverless cars frequently need human intervention, and nobody has yet designed a machine that can read reliably at the level of a sixth grader, let alone a college student. Computers that can educate themselves — a mark of true intelligence — remain a dream.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Daughters of Destiny’ and ‘Mad Max: Fury Road’
abstract: Five girls from India’s lowest caste work to change their fates. And Charlize Theron as Furiosa might be better than her performance in “Atomic Blonde.”
lead_paragraph: “Daughters of Destiny” follows five girls from India’s lowest caste who are hoping to change their fates. And “Mad Max: Fury Road” might just be even better than watching Charlize Theron in “Atomic Blonde.”

headline: Who Gets to Call the Game?
abstract: You don’t need to be a former player — or a particular gender — to analyze baseball.
lead_paragraph: It was another early summer baseball game last year at Chicago’s “friendly confines,” and in my expert opinion, the Cubs center fielder Dexter Fowler was playing too shallow. The newfangled analytics backed up my conclusion, and I could also draw on my playing days: having stood in the outfield in Wrigley Field, knowing the numbers can lie to you, especially given Wrigley’s unpredictable ricochets, ivy-covered entanglements and temperamental weather extremes.

Now one cruise company is making a fuller proposal by launching the first millennial-targeted cruise line.

headline: Drag Queens, a Metal Head and a Lot of Cowboy Hats in Tijuana, Mexico
abstract: “Walking around Tijuana, I noticed three main ideas — music, tradition and family — and those themes influenced the photographs I took,” Jake Michaels said.
lead_paragraph: In May and June, Jake Michaels was in Tijuana, a city he has visited several times in the seven years since he first began driving down from Southern California to attend soccer matches with friends along the border. He set out to explore the themes of music, family and tradition in Mexican culture, employing the vibrantly painted buildings as backdrops.

headline: A Doctor Gives Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop an Examination
abstract: Dr. Jen Gunter was already skeptical of “snake oil” products meant to improve women’s sex lives. Now she is a detractor of the movie star’s website.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jen Gunter, an obstetrician and gynecologist in the San Francisco Bay Area, didn’t mean to pick on Goop, Gwyneth Paltrow’s lifestyle and wellness e-commerce company. In fact, she’s a fan of Ms. Paltrow’s acting.

headline: Alisyn Camerota, Formerly of Fox News, Has a Story to Tell
abstract: The hair. The leg bronzer. Now at CNN, a journalist who accused Roger Ailes of harassment sets her first novel at a right-leaning cable network.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Gallo, the idealistic heroine of the new novel “Amanda Wakes Up,” is a morning anchor at FAIR News, a cable news network that brands itself as “True and Equal,” goes easy on right-wing provocateurs and mandates miniskirts and leg bronzer for its blond female hosts.

headline: Keeping Up, on Camera, Is No Longer Just for the Kardashians
abstract: A growing number of entrepreneurs are turning their lives into do-it-yourself reality shows, hiring videographers to document their every move.
lead_paragraph: This spring, John Henry, a 24-year-old entrepreneur and the founder of a Harlem-based nonprofit, had a very strange first date. The woman he had taken to a SoHo restaurant seemed to know a suspicious amount about the places he’d been in recent weeks and the conversations he’d had. This, Mr. Henry slowly realized, was a byproduct of his recent decision to have a videographer film large swaths of his daily life: his work, travels, lunches and even subway commutes, which Mr. Henry had then posted on Facebook and Instagram.

headline: For Jenny Allen, She and Her House ‘Were Sort of in This Together’
abstract: A Martha’s Vineyard retreat helped the writer Jenny Allen heal from the breakup of her marriage to the cartoonist and playwright Jules Feiffer.
lead_paragraph: MARTHA’S VINEYARD, Mass. — Not long after Jenny Allen left New York City to live full-time here, her once-sturdy farmhouse had a nervous breakdown. The pump to the well gave out, the water heater flooded the furnace, the pipes froze and an ancient tree crashed through the roof. It was 2013 and Ms. Allen, the journalist, humor writer and performer, had just separated from Jules Feiffer, the cartoonist and author to whom she had been married for 30 years, when the house began behaving like a kindergartner who had toughed it out all day at school only to have a meltdown at dismissal. You could see its collapse as a proxy for Ms. Allen’s own experience. “It was like the house knew that someone was there to take care of it so it just went …” Ms. Allen paused. “It just went ‘boing’ like a house in a cartoon.”

headline: ‘Dear Sugars’: How to Reclaim Vacation From Entitled Relatives
abstract: The Sugars tackle several questions, including what to do when your best friend’s husband asks you to lie and why we sometimes recoil at very public displays of grief.
lead_paragraph: In a heated moment, a mother reveals a dark chapter from her childhood to her daughter, then immediately regrets it. What now? In this week’s episode, the Sugars tackle this and several other questions, including how to handle a brother-in-law who treats your vacation as his own free childcare; what to do when your best friend’s husband asks you to lie; and why we sometimes recoil at very public displays of grief.

headline: After North Korea Test, South Korea Pushes to Build Up Its Own Missiles

headline: Will a Landlord Accept an Out-of-State Guarantor?

lead_paragraph: Q. My friends and I are planning to move to New York City from Ohio. We are all aspiring opera singers, so our combined income is not adequate to qualify for an apartment. We have cash saved, but do not have jobs yet, so we don’t have proof of employment. Instead, we plan to ask relatives to guarantee our lease. Do landlords accept guarantors who live outside the tristate area? If we have more than one guarantor, does each one have to earn enough to guarantee the entire lease, or will a landlord consider combined income?

headline: Mr. McCain and The Mooch

headline: From Voyeur to Friend

Not so wide that I can’t see many of the details inside their home. Several years ago, I watched them move in: a petite blond woman about my age and her husband.

headline: Empathy Gadgets
abstract: New tools can help doctors understand their patients.
lead_paragraph: The device slipped over my arm like a blood pressure cuff. Eight domino-size electrodes were pressed against my skin. I heard a series of beeps and felt a small electrical pulse, like a pinprick. Then, before I knew it, my arm was quivering like a bowl of gelatin.

headline: The Scars From ‘Bell-Ringing’ Football Tackles
abstract: A study has found overwhelming evidence that a brain disease is linked to football playing. So how will the N.F.L. take care of its players?

What began in 2004 as a sun-kissed, sometimes-bumbling lark finished in 2010 as a neo-romantic, industrial-smooth juggernaut. Teenagers who predated the constant self-broadcasting of the social-media era rapidly became television stars, doing their best to play the roles of teenagers who did not know they were being filmed. The genre had gone sentient. It would never look back.

headline: ‘Twin Peaks’ Season 3, Episode 12: Hornes Aplenty
abstract: This week’s episode gave us our first glimpse of a character we’d been waiting to see.
lead_paragraph: Because “Twin Peaks” doesn’t take place in the “real world” per se, it’s been fascinating in this revival to see just what aspects of modern life David Lynch and Mark Frost see fit to include in their story. I’ve already mentioned the unusually futuristic computers in the otherwise retro Twin Peaks police station; but throughout the series so far there’ve been more conventional signs that it’s taking place in the 2010s. The Double R Diner now touts its “RR2GO” service, for example; and at the Great Northern, Ben Horne is taken aback when he receives Agent Cooper’s old room key in the mail, because the hotel hasn’t used metal keys in years.

headline: Why We Shouldn’t Think About College as a Business
abstract: What’s lost when an education becomes a transaction.
lead_paragraph: We conventionally think of college as a place where you can discover new ideas, indulge curiosities and learn for the sake of learning. As tuition skyrockets and becomes less accessible for everyone, however, students have been compelled to think of college from a business perspective instead. In the 2010s, much of the discussion surrounding higher education is less about education and more about its suitability as an investment, like real estate or publicly traded stock.

headline: Britain Joins the Shift to Electric Cars

For years, countries — in particular Russia — have used cyberattacks and the dissemination of disinformation through social media and news outlets to provoke protests, sway elections and undermine trust in institutions. headline: What the ‘Government Schools’ Critics Really Mean

In a public talk, Sarah Lohman and Vivek Bald, two historians, will discuss Mr. Smile and the history of curry in American cuisine: “The Original Celebrity Chef: The King of Curry,” Aug. 10 from 7 to 8:30 p.m., $10 ($5 for members), Brooklyn Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont Street (Clinton Street), Brooklyn Heights, 718-222-4111, brooklynhistory.org.

headline: An Encore for the Native Americans Who Shook Up Rock ’n’ Roll
abstract: The new documentary “Rumble” brings to light often overlooked contributions, starting with the guitarist who invented the power chord.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of rock ’n’ roll songs have been banned from the airwaves because of their lyrics, but “Rumble” was the first to be banned because of its very sound. Recorded by Link Wray & His Ray Men in 1958, the instrumental pioneered the use of distortion, feedback and the power chord, a mix that made stations in New York and Boston so nervous they refused to play the song for fear that it might incite violence. According to popular lore, the hit song got its name because it reminded listeners of a gang fight, or at least a musical invitation to one; in “Pulp Fiction,” it’s the tune that plays while Uma Thurman and John Travolta share a $5 milkshake and a tense silence.

At their Sugar Hill Creamery, homemade ice creams and sorbets include vanilla, soursop and salted caramel crunch. Floats, milkshakes, sandwiches and hand-packed pints are also available: Sugar Hill Creamery, 184 Lenox Avenue (West 119th Street), 212-634-9004, sugarhillcreamery.com.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Los Angeles officials announced a deal Monday with the International Olympic Committee to play host to the 2028 Summer Olympics, giving up a bid for the 2024 Games to Paris and bringing the Olympics back to the United States for the first time since 2002.

headline: Chicago Cubs Give Steve Bartman a World Series Ring, Bejeweling an Infamous Hand
abstract: Bartman, reviled by many fans after he reached for a foul ball 14 years ago, was welcomed by the team, which sought “closure on an unfortunate chapter.”
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 14, 2003, a Cubs fan named Steve Bartman innocently reached up for a foul ball at Wrigley Field and initiated a cascading series of events that knocked his famously frustrated team right out of the postseason.

headline: Persian Gulf Rivals Competed to Host Taliban, Leaked Emails Show
abstract: The United Arab Emirates contends that Qatar’s hosting of a Taliban embassy is evidence of extremism. But the U.A.E. wanted to host it, too.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In their long-running rivalry, the United Arab Emirates has often accused its neighbor Qatar of abetting Islamist militants, citing as one prime example the 2013 opening of a Taliban embassy in the Qatari capital, Doha.

headline: Defying E.U. Court, Poland Is Cutting Trees in an Ancient Forest
keywords: ['Forests and Forestry', 'Logging Industry', 'World Heritage Sites', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The European Court of Justice had ordered a stop to logging in Bialowieza Forest, a Unesco World Heritage site.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Defying an order from the European Union’s highest court, the Polish government said on Monday that it would continue logging in Bialowieza Forest, the last primeval forest in Europe and a habitat for hundreds of bison.

headline: The Rugged Style of Sam Shepard
abstract: Probably no one else was more at ease in a pair of Levi’s and a simple T-shirt than he.

headline: When It Came to Style, Sam Shepard Was an Endangered Species
abstract: How the playwright and actor kept his cool, from the days of flower power to the age of social media.
lead_paragraph: He was, for so many, the archetypal American male given flesh and form (and a leather jacket). He was born in the heartland and worked on ranches in Duarte, Calif., where his family owned an avocado farm. He rode horses, sheared sheep, picked oranges, delivered newspapers. He had a volatile relationship with his father, a World War II fighter pilot who developed an alcohol problem, something that would later afflict the son.

headline: Will Shark Lovers Love ‘Unabomber’? Asking for a Cable Network.
abstract: The Discovery Channel, known for sometimes frivolous reality fare, hits the prestige-TV target with a mini-series about the hunt for a notorious mail bomber.
lead_paragraph: Let’s be honest: “Prestige television” and “Shark Week” are not phrases that go together naturally. Yet during its recent rather frivolous annual shark-themed programming stunt, the Discovery Channel was heavily promoting as laudable a series as TV has offered this summer: “Manhunt: Unabomber,” an eight-parter that begins on Tuesday night.

headline: View From the River Café: 40 Years of Feasts and Firsts
abstract: This special-occasion restaurant on the East River in Brooklyn was in many ways a pioneer, yet its understated charm and elegant owner still thrive.
lead_paragraph: Dining at a coveted window seat in the luminous River Café, which rests on a former coffee barge in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, even the most jaundiced New Yorkers have to concede that the magic endures.

headline: The Eclipse That Revealed the Universe
keywords: ['Eclipses', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Light', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Gravitation and Gravity']
abstract: In 1919, British astronomers photographed a solar eclipse and proved that light bends around our sun — affirming Einstein’s theory of general relativity.
lead_paragraph: So this is what it is like to play cosmic pinball. The worlds move, and sometimes they line up. Then you find yourself staring up the tube of blackness that is the moon’s shadow, a sudden hole in the sky during a total solar eclipse.

headline: Only Six Nations Have Evaluated Readiness for Global Pandemic
keywords: ['Epidemics', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: A World Bank-sponsored study found that wealthy countries Finland, Saudi Arabia and the United States and poor nations Eritrea, Pakistan and Tanzania had gone through assessments.
lead_paragraph: Of the world’s countries, only six — three rich ones and three poor ones — have taken the steps they should have to evaluate their ability to withstand a global pandemic, according to a recent report sponsored by the World Bank.

headline: Yankees Acquire Sonny Gray From Oakland as Trade Deadline Arrives
abstract: The deal bolsters the Yankees’ starting rotation as they make a determined bid to win the American League East and play deep into October.
lead_paragraph: A year ago at this time, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman had to persuade Hal Steinbrenner, the team’s general managing partner, to take a most un-Yankee-like approach to the trade deadline, advising him to shed well-known and highly paid players in exchange for unproven prospects.

headline: Kenyan Election Official Is Killed on Eve of Vote
keywords: ['Elections', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A senior election official in Kenya was found dead Monday, intensifying anxiety over whether the country can hold a fair and peaceful vote next week in a tightly contested presidential election.

headline: Instagram Turbocharges the Watch Market
abstract: A social media post sparks the sale of a 1969 Rolex “Paul Newman” Daytona for $175,000 within minutes.

On Wednesday, it had been an elegantly understated 1970 Rolex Submariner, courtesy of @jasonheaton, that quickened the pulse. Tuesday had brought its own obsession, a vintage Heuer 3647 Carrera chronograph, regrammed on @hodinkee.

headline: Chop Off This Worm’s Head and It Can Still Detect Light
abstract: Planarian flatworms can react to light when they lose their heads and brains, and gradually regain their ability to distinguish different hues as they regenerate their bodies.
lead_paragraph: The planarian flatworm is a smooshed noodle of an organism that can be found all over the planet. It has a triangular head occupied by a rather primitive version of a brain and two black dots for eyes. You can chop off this head, and it will grow back in about a week — eyes, brain and all. And you can hack away at the critter until all that’s left is a tiny speck of worm dust — and the thing will still grow back.

headline: Former Arizona Sheriff Joe Arpaio Is Convicted of Criminal Contempt
abstract: Prosecutors said he defied a judge’s orders to stop targeting Latinos — including citizens and legal immigrants — in a pattern of discriminatory policing.
lead_paragraph: Former Sheriff Joe Arpaio committed a crime by defying a court order to stop detaining suspected undocumented immigrants, a judge ruled on Monday, in the latest rebuke for a once-popular politician who was voted out of office last year.

headline: How to Save Your Sperm
abstract: We don’t just need safer chemicals, we need a whole new way of doing chemistry.
lead_paragraph: Is humanity killing itself off? In a study published last week, a team of epidemiologists found that sperm counts among men in the United States, Europe and Australia have declined by more than 50 percent between 1973 and 2011. Alongside the deleterious effects of cigarette smoke, especially during critical stages of prenatal development, the authors of the study point out that exposure to certain synthetic chemicals has been associated with decreased fertility.

headline: Don’t Refrigerate This Butter Dish
abstract: Butterie, available in multiple colors, stores a stick of butter at room temperature so it is ready to spread.
lead_paragraph: There are a couple of arguments for storing butter at room temperature. Left in a dish on the kitchen counter, it’s ready to spread at all times, and cooks will have soft butter without waiting. Joelle Mertzel, an entrepreneur, has created Butterie, a butter dish for the countertop, with a convenient built-in flip-top lid. The company had butter left at room temperature for three weeks tested for yeast, mold, bacteria and rancidity, and it was fine: Butterie, BPA-free plastic with spreader, $12.99 Bed Bath & Beyond stores, bedbathandbeyond.com; $13.99 (more colors available online), butteriedish.com.

headline: Q. and A.: The Cryptic Humanity of Melisandre on ‘Game of Thrones’
abstract: The actress Carice van Houten spoke about her role as the red priestess, whose latest prophecy hints at the character’s deepening sense of vulnerability.
lead_paragraph: The last time she was on Dragonstone, the red priestess Melisandre was on a mission to convert and support Stannis in his bid for the Iron Throne. It didn’t turn out well, for him or his family. So she moved on to Plan B (or C): to bring ice and fire together, to make sure Jon Snow and Daenerys Targaryen joined forces. After glimpsing Jon’s arrival from afar, she shared a few cryptic words with Varys, a fellow foreign-slave-turned-royal-councilor: “I have to die in this strange country, just like you.”

headline: Lee May, the Big Bopper for the Reds, Dies at 74
abstract: May, a slugging first baseman, was traded to the Astros before Cincinnati’s Big Red Machine really got rolling. The move felt like being “kicked out of the house,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Lee May, a slugging first baseman with the Cincinnati Reds who was traded to the Houston Astros for Joe Morgan after the 1971 season and missed the Reds’ becoming one of baseball’s greatest teams a few years later, died on Saturday in Cincinnati. He was 74.

headline: With ‘Logan Lucky,’ Soderbergh Hopes to Change Film’s Business Model
abstract: Steven Soderbergh wants to replicate what Hollywood studios do, only with fewer resources and more creative and economic control for filmmakers.
